This is the phase that begins when blades make contact (after Zufechten) and continues until you hit your opponent or disengage. Meyer (1570) particularly emphasizes Handarbeit as the middle phase where 'the greatest art and all speed which can take place in fencing' occurs. During Handarbeit, you: maintain blade contact through binds; feel (fühlen) your opponent's pressure to assess whether they're hard or soft; wind to bring your point to new openings while maintaining contact; execute techniques like Duplieren, Mutieren, Zucken, Durchwechseln, Schneiden (slicing), and others based on what you feel; work rapidly from one opening to another based on your opponent's reactions; potentially transition to grappling (Ringen am Schwert) at very close range. Execute Handarbeit by staying actively engaged in the bind: don't passively hold blade contact, but constantly work—feeling pressure, winding to openings, choosing techniques based on hard/soft states, maintaining offensive threat through continuous action. Your hands and blade should be in constant subtle motion, adjusting, winding, seeking openings. The Handarbeit phase requires the highest technical skill because you must make rapid tactical decisions based on tactile information (Fühlen) while maintaining structure, balance, and offensive pressure. This is where the system's sophistication appears: beginners only know how to strike, but advanced practitioners excel in Handarbeit where technique, sensitivity, and tactical intelligence dominate.
application: Use sophisticated binding/winding techniques based on feeling; where technical skill determines outcomes
fullApplication: Use the concept of Handarbeit to frame your approach to close-range combat with blade contact, emphasizing sophisticated technique over raw force. This phase excels at rewarding technical skill, tactical sensitivity, and rapid decision-making over physical attributes. Once you establish blade contact (from Zufechten or from any strike that's parried), immediately enter Handarbeit mindset: stay engaged with their blade, feel their pressure, and work continuously based on what you perceive. The goals during Handarbeit are: (1) Maintain blade contact when tactically advantageous—don't leave the bind unnecessarily, as contact gives you control and information. (2) Feel (Fühlen) continuously to assess their pressure state—hard, soft, or neutral—then choose appropriate techniques. (3) Wind constantly to bring your point toward openings while maintaining the safety of blade contact. Your point should always threaten; winding lets you change which opening you're threatening without losing contact. (4) Execute appropriate techniques based on pressure and situation: if hard, use yielding techniques (Zucken, Durchwechseln); if soft, use pressing techniques (winding to thrust, Mutieren). (5) Work rapidly and continuously—don't pause or think slowly. Handarbeit requires speed and fluidity: feel → decide → act, all nearly instantaneous. (6) Attack from one opening to another—if they defend one line, immediately work to the next opening. Keep them constantly defending. Practice Handarbeit extensively through bind-focused drilling: establish blade contact with training partners and practice all the binding/winding techniques with emphasis on feeling pressure and responding appropriately. This phase is where most of the system's technique catalog lives: winding, Duplieren, Mutieren, Zucken, Durchwechseln, Abschneiden (slicing), various wrestling applications, and more. Each technique is a tool for specific Handarbeit situations. Develop automatic responses: feel hard → execute yielding technique; feel soft → execute pressing technique. This should become instinctive through practice. Handarbeit also includes transitioning to wrestling (Ringen am Schwert) when appropriate: if you're in very close range with blade contact and opportunity arises, transition to grappling techniques, throws, disarms, or pommel strikes. Meyer emphasizes that Handarbeit 'comprises the greatest art'—this is where technical mastery matters most. Physical strength matters less in skilled Handarbeit because you're using leverage, timing, and technique rather than force. Practice continuous flow: establish bind, feel, wind, thrust/cut/slice based on opening and pressure, and if that's defended, immediately continue to next action. Never stop working in Handarbeit—maintain constant pressure and activity. The phase tests your ability to gather information through touch (Fühlen), make rapid tactical decisions, and execute techniques precisely under pressure. Remember that Handarbeit is not about desperately struggling in the bind but about skillful, efficient work that exploits every opportunity. Stay calm, feel constantly, make smart technique choices, and maintain offensive pressure throughout. Master Handarbeit and you become dangerous at close range where technical skill dominates, able to work efficiently in the bind to find and exploit openings that less skilled opponents cannot perceive or capitalize on. This is the heart of sophisticated longsword fencing.

briefDefinition: Exit phase to leave without being hit.
detailedDescription: Abzug (withdrawal, departing, pulling away) is the third and final phase of combat where you safely disengage from your opponent after an exchange, retreating from fighting range without being hit. Meyer (1570) particularly emphasizes Abzug as the third phase of his three-part combat model (Zufechten, Handarbeit, Abzug), though the concept of safe withdrawal exists throughout the longsword tradition. During Abzug, you: disengage from blade contact safely; retreat from fighting range while maintaining defensive structure; protect yourself against potential afterblows or pursuing attacks; return to a guard position that covers you during withdrawal. Execute Abzug by cutting away as you withdraw—don't simply pull back or turn away, but cut as you step back, creating a barrier that protects you during retreat. The cut-and-withdraw motion should be coordinated: as your feet move backward, your sword cuts to maintain a defensive barrier. You can withdraw to various guards: Pflug is often recommended as safest because your hands are low and protected while your point still threatens; Ochs can also work but leaves your hands more exposed. Your withdrawal should be deliberate and controlled, not panicked or rushed. You're creating space while maintaining structure and defensive capability. The Abzug acknowledges a practical reality: not every exchange ends with your opponent disabled, and you need to be able to leave the engagement safely. This is particularly important in practice/training contexts where you want to reset for another exchange, but it's equally important in real contexts where withdrawing safely after landing a hit (or after an inconclusive exchange) is crucial to avoid afterblows.
application: Use to retreat safely after exchanges; cut while stepping back to cover your withdrawal
fullApplication: Use the concept of Abzug to frame your approach to safe disengagement and withdrawal after exchanges have concluded. This phase excels at ensuring you don't get hit during retreat, teaching the tactical principle that leaving the fight safely is as important as entering it or fighting in it. After you've completed an exchange—whether you've hit your opponent, they've defended successfully, or the exchange has become inconclusive—initiate Abzug by withdrawing while maintaining defensive structure. The goals during Abzug are: (1) Disengage safely from blade contact without leaving yourself open to counters or pursuing attacks. (2) Retreat from fighting range back to safe distance while maintaining structure. Don't turn your back or drop your guard. (3) Protect against afterblows—your opponent may attempt to strike you as you withdraw, so maintain defensive capability throughout. (4) Return to a ready guard position, typically Pflug or another stance that covers you during withdrawal. Execute Abzug by cutting as you step backward: as you withdraw, cut in the direction you're moving (typically cutting down and back), creating a barrier with your sword that protects you during retreat. Your footwork should be controlled—step backward smoothly while maintaining balance, don't stumble or rush. Some instructors recommend specific withdrawal techniques: cut toward your opponent as you step back to maintain threat and coverage; recover to Pflug because it keeps your hands low and safe while your point still threatens forward (making it difficult for opponents to slash your arms during withdrawal); or use other cuts that create barriers as you retreat. Practice Abzug by drilling: complete an exchange (strike, bind, finish), then practice withdrawing safely with proper cutting and footwork. This should become automatic—after every exchange in practice, execute a proper Abzug rather than simply dropping your guard or turning away. The concept teaches important tactical awareness: every action has three parts (approaching/entering, working, leaving), and neglecting the third part leaves you vulnerable. In training contexts, good Abzug allows you to reset safely for the next exchange. In competitive contexts, it prevents afterblows and demonstrates control. In hypothetical real contexts, it ensures you don't get hit after landing your attack, as historical sources note that many fighters were injured during or after their own successful attacks. Meyer emphasizes Abzug as completing the tactical cycle: you enter deliberately (Zufechten), work skillfully (Handarbeit), and leave safely (Abzug). Master all three phases for complete tactical competence. Practice Abzug consciousness: in all training, don't just think about entering and hitting, but also think about leaving safely afterward. Make safe withdrawal habitual. Some variations of Abzug include not just cutting away but using other defensive actions: maintaining blade contact and pressing them backward as you retreat; executing specific techniques like Hendedrucken (pressing their hands/arms painfully to force them back); or transitioning through specific guard sequences that provide coverage during withdrawal. The key principle is that withdrawal should be active and defensive, not passive. Don't just retreat—cut, cover, maintain structure, and ensure you're not exposed to counters during your departure. Remember that the fight isn't over until you've safely disengaged, so treat Abzug with the same tactical attention as the other phases. Master Abzug and you complete your technical toolkit, ensuring you can enter safely, work skillfully, and leave safely—the full cycle of competent fencing.

briefDefinition: Disarms, throws, pommel strikes once blades are engaged.
detailedDescription: Ringen am Schwert (wrestling at the sword, grappling with the sword) refers to all grappling, throwing, and close-combat techniques executed when swords are still in hand but fighters are at very close range. This represents the closest range of longsword combat, beyond the range where cutting and binding dominate. These techniques involve: throwing your opponent using your sword as a lever against their neck, arms, or body; disarming techniques (Schwertnehmen) where you strip away or control their sword; pommel strikes to the head, face, or body; arm locks and joint manipulations that disable or control; body-to-body wrestling that uses your sword for leverage while employing throws, trips, and takedowns. Execute Ringen am Schwert by first closing to very close range (often through Durchlaufen - running through), then immediately transitioning from sword techniques to wrestling techniques that incorporate the sword as a tool. Grip your sword at both hilt and blade to give yourself more control and leverage options—the sword becomes a rigid lever you can use against your opponent's body, neck, or arms. Common techniques include: placing your blade across their neck and using it as a lever to throw them backward; hooking their arms or neck with your blade and pulling/pushing to disrupt their balance; striking with your pommel to their head or face from close range; controlling their sword arm and using leverage to force them to release their weapon; various throws and takedowns that use your sword for additional leverage or control. Your wrestling skills become primary at this range—the sword enhances your grappling rather than replacing it.
application: Use at very close range; integrate wrestling techniques with sword leverage for throws, disarms, and strikes
fullApplication: Use Ringen am Schwert when you've closed to very close range where traditional sword techniques no longer work effectively, integrating wrestling skills with your sword to control, throw, disarm, or strike your opponent. This phase excels at ending fights decisively through grappling techniques enhanced by the sword as a leverage tool. The techniques apply when: (1) You've deliberately closed range through Durchlaufen (running through) and are now inside their reach. (2) In Handarbeit (close work), you've closed even tighter and have opportunity for wrestling. (3) Your opponent attempts to close on you and you need grappling responses. (4) The fight has naturally moved to very close range through the flow of exchange. Execute Ringen am Schwert by smoothly transitioning from sword technique to wrestling technique: maintain contact with their sword or body, then immediately apply grappling techniques that use your sword as enhancement. Common applications include: Throws using your sword as lever—place your blade against their neck, under their arm, or across their body, then use it as a rigid lever to throw them by pulling, pushing, or torquing. Trip them while using sword pressure to break their balance. Disarms (Schwertnehmen)—grab their blade or hilt, control their weapon with leverage, and strip it away or force them to release it. This often involves trapping their sword against your body or using two hands against their one. Pommel strikes—at very close range, release one hand from your sword and strike with your pommel to their head, face, or body. The heavy pommel makes an effective impact weapon at this range. Arm locks and controls—use your sword to trap or lever their arms, applying joint locks that force them to submit, drop their weapon, or move where you want. Wrestling throws and takedowns—apply standard wrestling techniques (hip throws, trips, takedowns) while using your sword for additional leverage, control, or off-balancing. Practice Ringen am Schwert with appropriate protective gear since these techniques involve close physical contact and potential falls. Train the transition from sword techniques to wrestling: practice moving smoothly from Handarbeit or Durchlaufen into wrestling applications. Develop your general wrestling skills as foundation—Ringen am Schwert requires competent grappling ability enhanced by the sword, not just sword technique. Study historical sources for specific techniques: many manuscripts show detailed Ringen am Schwert plays with specific throws, disarms, and strikes. Practice these historically-documented techniques to build your close-range toolkit. Remember that at very close range, your sword becomes a multipurpose tool: a lever for throws, a rigid bar for locks and controls, an impact weapon (pommel and crossguard), and a means to control their weapon. Use all these functions as situations demand. Ringen am Schwert teaches that longsword combat includes all ranges: from long cuts through middle binding to close wrestling—you must be competent at all ranges to be a complete fighter. Don't neglect this range in training. Practice deliberately closing to wrestling range, applying techniques, and transitioning back to sword range when appropriate. Master Ringen am Schwert and you become dangerous at all ranges, able to wrestle effectively even with swords in hand, using the weapon to enhance rather than limit your grappling options.

briefDefinition: Control/strip the opponent's weapon from contact.
detailedDescription: Schwertnehmen (sword-taking, disarming) refers specifically to techniques for taking away or disarming your opponent's sword, typically executed at very close range as part of Ringen am Schwert (wrestling at the sword). These techniques involve controlling your opponent's weapon through leverage, joint manipulation, or force, then removing it from their grasp. Execute Schwertnehmen by: grabbing their blade or hilt with one or both hands while controlling it with your own sword; using leverage to force their weapon away from their body or out of their hands; applying joint locks to their wrist or arm that make holding their sword painful or impossible; trapping their sword against your body or using your crossguard to hook and control it; using two-hand advantage against their one hand by grabbing their hilt or blade with one of your hands while maintaining your own weapon; applying sudden force or torque that breaks their grip. The techniques often involve gripping their blade safely (at the flat or near the crossguard) or grabbing their hilt, then using mechanical advantage to twist, pull, or lever the sword away. Your own sword may be used to trap, hook, or control their weapon while your free hand performs the actual stripping motion. Some techniques involve stepping or body positioning that creates angles where their sword can be controlled and removed. Schwertnehmen typically requires very close range where you can reach their weapon with your hands, and often emerges from Ringen am Schwert situations where you're grappling with swords still in hand.
application: Use at very close range when opportunity arises to grab and control their weapon; strip it away using leverage
fullApplication: Use Schwertnehmen techniques when you're at very close range (typically during Ringen am Schwert) and opportunity arises to control and remove your opponent's weapon, ending the fight by disarming them. These techniques excel at decisive endings: without their weapon, your opponent is defeated (in training/competition) or at severe disadvantage (in historical context). Schwertnehmen opportunities typically arise when: (1) You've closed to wrestling range through Durchlaufen or close Handarbeit, bringing you within reach of their hilt or blade. (2) Their weapon is positioned where you can safely grab it—often when they've overextended, when it's bound or trapped, or when you've moved inside their guard. (3) You've controlled their arms or body in ways that limit their ability to withdraw or reorient their weapon. Execute Schwertnehmen by identifying the opportunity, immediately controlling their weapon with one hand (grabbing blade at flat, grabbing hilt, or hooking with your crossguard), then using leverage to strip it away. Common methods include: Two-hands-against-one: grab their hilt with one hand while maintaining your own weapon with your other hand, using your mechanical advantage to twist or pull their sword from their grip. Lever-strip: trap their blade against your body or with your sword, then use your free hand to grab and twist their hilt, levering the weapon from their hands. Joint-lock disarm: apply wrist or arm lock that forces them to release their weapon to avoid injury. Crossguard-hook: use your crossguard to hook their blade, then twist and pull to strip it away. Step-and-strip: step to create angles that give you leverage on their weapon, then pull or twist it away. Practice Schwertnehmen carefully with training weapons and protective gear, as these techniques involve close contact and weapon control. Start slowly to learn the mechanics, then gradually increase speed and resistance. Train the recognition of opportunities: not every moment allows Schwertnehmen—you must identify when their weapon is positioned favorably and when you have sufficient control to attempt disarming. Poor timing leads to failure or worse, losing your own weapon. Study historical sources for specific Schwertnehmen techniques: manuscripts show various specific disarms with details about gripping, leverage, and footwork. Practice these documented techniques as foundation for your close-range toolkit. Remember that disarming is high-reward (ends the fight decisively) but requires specific conditions (very close range, favorable weapon position, sufficient control). Don't force Schwertnehmen attempts when conditions aren't right. Schwertnehmen connects to broader principles of close-range combat: once you're at wrestling range, everything becomes viable—strikes, throws, disarms, locks. Use whatever technique the situation favors. Practice transitions: after successful Schwertnehmen, immediately follow with controlling actions (they may try to regain a weapon or close to unarmed grappling). Master Schwertnehmen and you add decisive disarming techniques to your close-range arsenal, able to end fights by removing your opponent's weapon when opportunities arise.

briefDefinition: Opposite of true edge; key in Schielhau/windings.
detailedDescription: Kurze Schneide (short edge, false edge, back edge) refers to the edge of the longsword blade that faces away from you when you hold the sword in a normal grip, opposite the Lange Schneide (long edge/true edge). On a double-edged longsword, this is the edge that would face backward if you held the sword with the true edge forward. The short edge is called 'short' not because of its physical length but because it's on the 'short' or back side of the blade relative to your hand position and body. In a standard grip with quillons horizontal, the short edge is the one facing upward (toward your thumb if using thumb grip). The short edge is used for specific cuts and techniques where you strike with the back of the blade rather than the primary edge. Important applications of the short edge include: the Schielhau (squinting strike) which is typically delivered with the short edge from certain positions; certain Zwerchhau (thwart strike) variations, particularly when striking from the right side; various winding actions that rotate the blade to bring the short edge into play; some binding and parrying positions that use the short edge to control the opponent's blade. Using the short edge typically requires rotating your hands and wrists to present this edge forward. When cutting with the short edge, your hand position and body mechanics differ from true edge cuts—often involving more wrist rotation and different body angles.
application: Use for specific techniques requiring back-edge strikes; essential in Schielhau and certain Zwerchhau variations
fullApplication: Use the short edge (Kurze Schneide) deliberately in techniques that specifically call for it, understanding that this back edge serves important tactical purposes in the longsword system. While the long edge is primary for most cuts, the short edge enables specific techniques and tactical options that expand your capabilities. The short edge appears in several key techniques: Schielhau often uses the short edge, particularly when delivered from certain angles—the blade rotates during the strike to present the short edge forward, allowing you to strike with specific mechanics that support the Schielhau's tactical purpose of breaking Pflug and countering thrusts. Zwerchhau from the right side frequently uses the short edge—as you strike horizontally from your right, rotating your hands brings the short edge forward, creating the characteristic high horizontal strike. Winding actions may rotate your blade to bring the short edge against your opponent's blade or toward targets, giving you additional options for edge orientation in the bind. Certain binding positions naturally place your short edge forward, and you can use this edge to control or press against your opponent's blade. Practice short edge techniques by focusing on the hand rotation required: when striking with the short edge, your hands must turn to present this edge forward, which feels different from true edge strikes. Your thumbs typically rotate toward the target (whereas with true edge, your knuckles rotate toward target). Drill the specific techniques that use short edge: practice Schielhau with proper hand rotation to deliver the short edge; practice Zwerchhau from right side with short edge; practice winding in the bind that transitions between edges. Develop edge awareness: know at all times which edge is forward and be able to transition between edges deliberately through proper winding and rotation. The short edge teaches an important principle: a double-edged sword gives you two edges to work with, expanding your tactical options beyond single-edge weapons. Don't limit yourself to only the long edge—use both edges as techniques demand. Historical sources specifically mention short edge techniques and positions, indicating this was a deliberate and important aspect of longsword technique, not an afterthought. Some techniques work better or only work with specific edges—respect these technical requirements by using the correct edge. Practice edge control: in all binding and winding work, maintain awareness of which edge is engaged with your opponent's blade and which edge is threatening openings. This awareness lets you choose appropriate techniques based on current edge orientation. Remember that while most basic cuts use the long edge for simplicity and power, advanced techniques frequently employ the short edge for specific tactical purposes. Master both edges and you have complete technical control of your sword, able to strike and work effectively with whichever edge the situation favors.

briefDefinition: Main edge for most cuts and strong parries.
detailedDescription: Lange Schneide (long edge, true edge, primary edge) refers to the edge of the longsword blade that faces forward when you hold the sword in a normal grip, aligned with your knuckles and naturally positioned for cutting. On a double-edged longsword, this is the edge that faces toward your target when you hold the sword ready to strike. The long edge is called 'long' not because of its physical length but because it's on the 'long' or forward side of the blade relative to your hand position and body—it's the edge you naturally lead with. In a standard grip with quillons horizontal, the long edge is the one facing downward (toward your knuckles if using standard grip). The long edge is the primary cutting edge used for most techniques: the majority of cuts (Oberhau, Unterhau, Mittelhau) are delivered with the long edge; most defensive positions and parries use the long edge to control the opponent's blade; binding and winding work often maintains long edge forward; techniques like Zornhau, Krumphau, and Scheitelhau typically use the long edge. Using the long edge is mechanically natural and powerful because it aligns with your body structure and delivers force effectively. When cutting with the long edge, your knuckles lead the strike, your forearms remain relatively untwisted, and your body mechanics support powerful edge-on-target impact. The long edge provides the strongest structure for parrying because it aligns with your hand and arm position naturally.
application: Use as primary edge for most cuts, parries, and bindings; natural alignment with body mechanics
fullApplication: Use the long edge (Lange Schneide) as your primary cutting edge for most techniques, understanding that this edge represents your natural, powerful, and structurally sound option for the majority of longsword work. The long edge should be your default for most situations because it offers mechanical advantages: natural alignment with your body structure, powerful cutting mechanics, strong defensive positions, and intuitive edge orientation. Most fundamental techniques use the long edge: all basic Oberhau (descending cuts) use the long edge; most Unterhau (rising cuts) use the long edge; many Mittelhau (middle cuts) use the long edge; the Zornhau uses the long edge; the Krumphau typically uses the long edge; the Scheitelhau uses the long edge. When binding, the long edge forward gives you strong structure and good control options. When parrying with techniques like Absetzen, the long edge provides solid interception of incoming attacks. Practice edge awareness: know that your long edge is forward most of the time and develop strong technique with this edge before worrying excessively about short edge techniques. Master the fundamentals: powerful cutting with the long edge, strong binding with the long edge, effective parrying with the long edge. These are the foundation of longsword technique. The long edge also provides advantages in edge alignment: because it's naturally aligned with your knuckles, you can use your knuckle position as a guide to ensure proper edge orientation during cuts—if your knuckles are aimed at the target, your long edge is likely aligned correctly. When practicing cuts, focus on long edge mechanics: lead with your knuckles, keep your forearms relatively aligned (not twisted), drive the edge through the target with body rotation and extension. These mechanics create powerful, clean cuts that utilize the long edge effectively. The historical sources primarily describe long edge techniques, with short edge techniques appearing in specific special applications. This indicates that the long edge was considered primary, with the short edge as supplementary. When binding with the long edge forward, you have strong structure and can press effectively, wind to bring your point online, or maintain control. This is why most binding work defaults to long edge engagement. Practice defending with the long edge: techniques like Absetzen specifically use long edge to intercept and control incoming attacks, combining defense and offense effectively. The long edge gives you strong structure for this simultaneous defend-and-threaten approach. Remember that while the short edge has important specific uses, the long edge remains your primary tool for most situations. Develop strong long edge technique as foundation, then add short edge techniques as refinements that expand your tactical options. Master the long edge and you master the core of longsword technique: powerful cuts, strong bindings, effective defenses, all built on mechanically sound use of your primary cutting edge.

briefDefinition: Tip; essential in Zornhau-ort and Absetzen.
detailedDescription: Ort (point, tip) refers to the pointed end of the longsword blade, the primary tool for thrusting and the central threatening element in much of the German longsword tradition. The point is not just a physical feature but a tactical concept—historical sources repeatedly emphasize that 'the point threatens and finishes' while cuts prepare and create opportunities. The point's importance stems from several factors: it travels the shortest distance to the target (straight line rather than arc), making thrusts faster than cuts; it can threaten continuously from guards like Ochs, Pflug, and Langort; it delivers decisive attacks that end exchanges; it controls centerline and dominates space; it serves as both offensive weapon and defensive tool. The point features prominently in many techniques: all thrusts (Stich) use the point to penetrate; Zornhau-Ort is a fundamental follow-up where you thrust along the opponent's blade after binding; Absetzen uses the point to threaten while parrying; Langort and Sprechfenster position the point forward to control space and gather information; winding brings the point online toward openings while maintaining blade contact; Ansetzen immediately places the point onto openings as they appear. The point should remain threatening constantly—even when cutting, your point should return to threatening position quickly. Good point control means keeping the point stable, online, and directed toward targets, not wavering or wandering offline during actions.
application: Keep point threatening constantly; use for all thrusts and as primary finishing tool after cuts create opportunities
fullApplication: Use the point (Ort) as your primary threatening and finishing tool, understanding that the point is central to the entire German longsword tradition. While cuts are important, the historical sources make clear that the point is supreme: 'the point threatens and finishes.' Your point should constantly threaten your opponent, forcing them to respect and defend against the immediate danger it represents. The point appears throughout the system: In guards, position your point to threaten constantly—Ochs and Pflug point forward at face/chest; Langort extends the point directly at the opponent; even guards that appear more withdrawn should quickly transition to pointing threat. In attacks, use the point as your finishing tool: after cuts create openings or establish binds, thrust with the point to exploit those opportunities. The Zornhau-Ort exemplifies this: strike Zornhau, bind, immediately thrust along their blade with your point. In defense, use the point to threaten even while defending: Absetzen parries by extending your point, simultaneously defending and threatening. After any parry, your point should immediately seek openings. In binding work, constantly wind to bring your point online toward openings—the entire winding system revolves around keeping your point threatening while maintaining blade contact. Practice point control extensively: your point should be stable, directed, and threatening at all times. Wobbly, wandering, or offline points are less threatening and less effective. Develop the ability to keep your point online even as your body moves, even as you cut, even during complex footwork. The point should feel like an extension of your awareness, constantly seeking and threatening targets. In the sources, the principle is clear: cuts provoke reactions and create opportunities (they force parries, displace guards, establish binds), but the point finishes—once the opportunity exists, the thrust ends the exchange. Practice this pattern: cut to create opportunity → thrust with point to exploit opportunity. Your cutting work sets up your thrusting work. The point also controls distance and centerline: by extending your point forward (Langort, Sprechfenster), you create a barrier your opponent must deal with before they can reach you. This gives you control of space and tempo—they must address your point before implementing their attacks. Practice distance control with the point: extend fully to create maximum threat and space control, making your opponent work around or through your point to reach you. The point enables instant attacks: because it travels in a straight line rather than an arc, thrusts arrive faster than cuts. Use this speed advantage when you need immediate hits—the moment an opening appears, your point should be driving toward it. Historical sources emphasize: 'learn to thrust from all guards' and 'the point must always threaten the face or chest.' This means that regardless of what guard you're in, you should be able to thrust immediately, and your point should always be positioned to threaten vital targets. Practice thrusting from all positions: from high guards, low guards, left and right, from the bind, from all situations. The point should be usable instantly from any position. Remember that point control separates skilled from unskilled: beginners have wobbly, inconsistent points; advanced practitioners have steady, threatening, constantly online points. Develop this control through dedicated practice. Master the point and you master the heart of the German longsword tradition: the constant threat that forces your opponent to defend, the shortest and fastest path to target, the primary finishing tool that ends exchanges decisively.

briefDefinition: A purposeful miss to provoke and change through.
detailedDescription: Fehlen (feinting, missing, failing) refers to deliberately missing or shortening an attack to provoke a reaction from your opponent, then exploiting that reaction by changing to a different attack. This is a deceptive technique where your apparent attack is actually a setup for your real attack. Execute Fehlen by beginning a strike or thrust that appears committed and threatening, causing your opponent to react (typically by parrying or moving to defend that line), but intentionally keep the attack short or pull it just before completion, then immediately redirect to a different line where they're now open. The key is making the initial attack appear genuine enough that they must react, but maintaining control so you can change direction instantly. Your feint must be convincing: if they don't react because they recognize it as a feint, the technique fails. Common applications include: striking toward one opening to draw their parry, then changing through (Durchwechseln) under their blade to thrust to the opposite opening; beginning a cut to make them raise their defense, then pulling back and striking low where they've opened; threatening high to make them cover high, then immediately attacking low. Fehlen must be used judiciously—Liechtenauer's system generally emphasizes committed, genuine attacks over deceptive feints. The sources contain relatively little explicit emphasis on feinting compared to other systems, suggesting feints should be used selectively rather than as primary tactics. When used, feints should setup higher-percentage attacks, not become an end in themselves.
application: Use sparingly to draw reactions; threaten one line to open another, then change through to the opened line
fullApplication: Use Fehlen (feinting) sparingly and deliberately to provoke specific reactions that create openings for your real attacks. While feinting is a valid tactical tool, the Liechtenauer tradition emphasizes committed, genuine attacks more than deceptive feints—use feints as occasional tactical variations rather than primary approaches. Fehlen works when: your opponent is defensive and prone to parrying, making them susceptible to feints that draw their parries; you need to open a specific line that's currently defended; you want to gather information about their reactions and defensive patterns. Execute Fehlen by making your initial attack appear genuine and threatening enough that they must respond—if they don't believe your feint, they won't react and the technique fails. Strike or thrust with apparent commitment toward one opening, causing them to move to defend that line (raising their sword, shifting position, committing to a parry), then immediately change your attack to a different line that's now open because of their reaction. Common Fehlen applications include: Feint high, strike low: begin a descending strike toward their head, causing them to raise their defense, then immediately pull back and cut low to their legs or body where they've opened by raising high. Feint one side, thrust other: begin a cut to one side to draw their parry, then change through (Durchwechseln) under their parrying blade to thrust to the opposite side. Feint thrust, cut: begin a thrust that makes them defend against it, then change to a cut that comes around their thrust defense. Feint to provoke Nachreisen: deliberately miss short, making them attempt to counter your 'miss,' then strike them during their counter attempt. Practice Fehlen with restraint: the Liechtenauer tradition values committed attacks that create genuine threats and establish binds where you can work with advantage. Overuse of feints can make you tentative and prevent you from establishing strong positions. The sources suggest feinting is a valid tool but not the primary approach—most teaching emphasizes striking directly to openings with commitment, establishing binds, and working in those binds based on feeling (Fühlen). Use Fehlen when it serves specific tactical purposes, not as your default approach. The technique appears in various forms in the sources: Durchwechseln can be used as a feint (threaten one side, change through when they defend); Zucken can function as feint (bind, pull away when they press, strike the opening); even certain guard positions can feint (appear to threaten one line, suddenly change to attack another). Practice making feints convincing: your initial attack must appear real enough that skilled opponents react to it. Half-hearted or obviously fake feints waste time and energy without creating opportunities. Commit to your feint as if it's real, only changing at the last moment when their reaction appears. Remember that good opponents may not react predictably to feints—they may not take the bait, or they may respond in unexpected ways. Be prepared to adapt if your feint doesn't produce the expected reaction. Against skilled opponents, frequent feinting may become ineffective as they learn to ignore or counter your feints. Master Fehlen as a tactical tool you can deploy when situations favor it, but maintain Liechtenauer's emphasis on committed, genuine attacks as your primary approach. Use feints to add tactical variety and to solve specific defensive problems, but don't make them your core strategy. The best use of Fehlen is occasional and surprising: if you usually attack directly and genuinely, your occasional feint will be more effective because opponents won't expect it.
